content.description: Start on electroglide, but continue straight up the blunt arete. Great midway roof crux.
Awesome climbing on a unique formation. Start in the chimney and follow bolts up the ever steepening "T-Rex".
A textbook one move wonder. Begin behind a large boulder. Head up, trending slightly to the left to the base of the obvious roof. Crush the short crux and clip the chains.

This route climbs straight up from the arete just left of Barley and Hops and continues up the face above. After a bouldery start, the grade eases to 5.7ish climbing with just enough pro every now and again. The lack of information, lichen covered holds, and sporadic pro made this feel a little more adventurous than the grade would suggest. 

  Note: I'm not sure if this route already exists under a different name somewhere, but I couldn't easily find anything on it. Please comment below or contact me if you have any information about this line.
content.protection: Finger to hand sized cams and a set of stoppers. The gear isn't great, but it's there. The route finishes left of the anchors for 420 - step right and clip them. Some cordelette will allow you to redirect the anchor over the ledge so it's better positioned for a top-rope or to rap.
content.location: This is a few feet before the property line fence where Hickadelic Jazzgrass goes up. It starts on the rounded arete just left of Barley and Hops and goes straight up from there (see picture). B & H presumably traverses left and joins this line above the dihedral roof.

content.description: Climbing blocks and flakes up a dihedral. Progressively widening crack, leads to offwidth/squeeze chimney inside the crack or easy stemming and jugs outside the crack. Finish up low 5th terrain.
content.protection:
Fingers and hands with a 3 or 4 to protect the low 5th at the top. 

  No fixed anchors. Webbing on tree, may or may not be there.
content.location: Prominent dihedral right of Milquetoast and Beefcake.

content.description: A boulder problem start leads to some slab climbing and a big ledge. Climb overhanging rock off the ledge to a two bolt anchor. Don't fall clipping the anchor.
content.protection: Nine bolts and a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This route starts in a scoop on the left hand side of the Confederate Cracks area.

content.description: Cool crux around the third bolt leads into to some easier fun climbing.
content.protection: 8 bolts and 2 bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: Just to the right of Milquetoast.

content.description: If only it were clean, we would have another classic. Start up the slab and move into the hanging arete. Turn the roof and get it all back before heading up the moss coated headwall, which becomes increasingly more difficult the higher you go.
Climbs an arete with cool boiler plate jugs. Good exposure.
content.location: Walk until you hit the fence. Hickedelic Jazz Grass is the route that sits immediately inside the fence.

content.description: (From new guidebook) Excellent alternative to pumpy overhangs! Several 5.9 moves lead up this less than vertical face with a technical crux.
content.location: Climber's left of Meatcake and Milquetoast

content.description:
Climb a blank less than vertical arete, clipping the first bolt.  Transition right and rest at a small ledge, clipping the second and third bolts.  Use a series of micro features to overcome the crux and clip the forth bolt.  Ascend easier, moss covered terrain to the anchor. 

  As someone who enjoys delicate near-vertical climbing I found this route enjoyable.  The first half features challenging climbing divided by a full recovery rest.  The last half of the route is forgettable.
content.protection: Approximately 7 bolts, the 4th of which is fixed, and an anchor.
content.location: This route is located between 420 and Captain Disco.

content.description: Tricky face climbing leads to a fun crux pulling the roof.
content.protection: 4 permas, 3 bolts and two sport anchors.
content.location: Roof just left of The Catholic Boat, cut left in the beginning for Electroglide. Going direct goes at 12b.

content.description: Good hands to some blocky climbing. Finish up a dihedral with wide cups or fists.
content.protection: 0.5" to 4"   Rap rings at the top
content.location: Less than vertical hand crack to the right of several routes out the big roof. Crack leads to steeper climbing in a dihedral up higher.

content.description: Hard moves around bolt 2 leads to easier climbing and a small roof before the top.
content.location: Sport route left of Dirty Crack Whore. Left of Haasenpfeffer.

content.description: Start on the arête right of the acute dihedral as you would for Meatcake (a little bouldery) and then stay with the crack as it goes around the corner and splits the face. You can clip the first bolt of Meatcake (use a long sling) or not and plug in small to medium size gear up the crack until it dies out. Move up and left and clip the bolt on Meatcake. Finish on that route. Best to use long runners on the bolts to reduce ropedrag. Tough to place gear at the top of the crack. Best to run it out a little. The climbing is moderate through that section.
content.protection: 4 bolts and small to medium sized cams. Anchors are equipped with lowering biners.

content.description:
This is the clean dihedral to the right of Hickadelic Jazzgrass. Pull the overhanging start onto thin, balancey stems above small, shallow placements. Traverse out left at the roof and follow moderate, lichen-covered holds to the top. 

  This route would be 3 stars if anchors were installed after exiting the roof.
content.protection: Small gear for the cruxy dihedral. SR for the rest. On top, reach right to the anchors of 420.
content.location: Head all the way to the fence at the end of the West side, then backtrack a few feet. Just to the right of Hickadelic Jazzgrass.

content.description: Climb the crack between Captain Disco and Haasenpfeffer, finishing on the Captain Disco anchors.
content.protection: rack to #5 cam, shared sport anchors
content.location: Not far from the property line, look for a crack climb behind a large boulder in the corner between Disco and Haasen.

content.description: Well defined crux at second bulge (4th bolt).
content.location: Second bolted route north (right) of boundary fence. Start on the right side of dihedral/crack.

content.description: Lots of shade and much less crowded that the more popular North Forty.
